Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2011 12:55PM thegood5 wrote: question for all you ladies who have started...I forgot to ask my nurse today ("dress rehearsal", rads start Mon) if the road map she drew on my chest would be there the entire 33 treatments, or if they just use them in the beginning?    I even have one on my neck...lovely.  Looks like a really bad tattoo, in a very odd place.  Glad I will just be camping this weekend and not going to a wedding!    I also found out from my nurse that I can use deodorant on my rads side, something called "Toms" or something like that, which she said can be found in my local grocery stores.
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2011 07:49PM thegood5 wrote: Good morning everyone!  I've been hanging out on  the March rads thread since I was supposed to start in March, but due to a 2nd lumpec, I will be starting in about a week.  I go today to have my simulation and will find out when this journey will begin.  I also am on herceptin every 3 weeks, and will be for however long it keeps working for me since I have 1 liver met.  Anxious to get started on this! I was told by my rads nurse to buy a sports bra 2 sizes larger to wear during rads, if I even want to wear one at all.  I also bought mens "wife beaters" tshirts in smalls to wear around the house, cheap and not a biggie if they get stained.  Wishing you all the best as you proceed with your treatments!
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Loving the facebook entries...one morning my status was my excitement about waking up with bed head!

Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2011 12:57AM thegood5 wrote: wow Miz-chiz, glad to hear you are ok after your fall...ouch!  I've been done with chemo since the end of Jan. and my hair is looking like it's a buzz cut that's getting a little too long, about an inch on top and 1/2-3/4 in. in the back and sides.  Hang in there, it will grow!
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: May 3, 2011 08:45AM - edited May 3, 2011 08:46AM by thegood5 ducky, I agree...start the creams now!I started putting it on the week before rads, just to prep my skin.  NOT that the Doc's dont know what they are talking about, but I would rather go by the girls on this and the March thread, who have been thru the actual radiation and know what it feels like...they are full of great tips.  I put the cream on right after rads, again in the afternoon, and at bedtime I put on the aquaphore with a mens undershirt that fits fairly tight.  Good luck to all!
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: May 4, 2011 11:15PM thegood5 wrote: 13/33 done today!  Usually if I have to wait at all back in the waiting room where you sit there with strangers in a hospital gown, (lovely) I am sitting there with older men, feeling very uncomfortable.  This morning there was a problem with the woman before me so I had to sit there for an extra 20 minutes waiting...no biggie.  A woman came out and was waiting for her appt.  She sat down next to me and started off with a "sweet girl, what on earth are you doing here?!".  Then when she found out I was "only" 40, she just couldn't believe it.  She went on to tell me that this is her 2nd bout with the beast, and that she is doing well.  Today was her last rads...40 all together.  I was wishing I could have sat and talked with her for hours, but they called her back.  I told her that I wanted to be able to hear that bell ring when she was done and she said that wouldn't be all I would hear, and she was right.  I was lucky enough to still be there when she came out and I got to witness her ring that bell, jump around, scream and sing.  This woman was a complete stranger to me and yet she brought so much happiness to my day.  Just another reminder that we're all in this together, and we can rely on one another.  Love you all
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 10:39AM thegood5 wrote: hdangelbaby~everyone is different in the way they feel, but I cannot imagine that you would be even close to being able to lift stuff with the radiation going to your armpit.  I just got my 4th one this morning and can already feel that my armpit is getting a little sore, and when my arm is down at my side, the rubbing really hurts.  like I have said before and I'll say it again, NO ONE can really understand the se's unless they have been thru it themselves.  Has your onc ever had radiation to his armpit?...doubtful!  You do what you feel is best.  If it were me, I would definitly wait til I was totally done.  I had a lumpectomy too and can hardly reach up to grab a glass out of a cabinet!  Good luck in your decision!
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: May 7, 2011 07:08PM thegood5 wrote: left side is definitly turning red...had to laugh, when I would wear a bikini (those days are long gone...)my hubby would say I glow in the dark from my tan skin/white boobs, or that they looked like headlights.  Last night when I put on the aloe, I was laughing so hard and told him I am now a "padidle"...ever play that game while driving and you see a car with just one headlight and you yell "padidle!"?  well, that's me now....
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2011 12:57PM thegood5 wrote: Just got home from my 1st treatment.  After hearing about all of those big noisy machines on the March thread, I was really nervous.  I guess every place is different, because when I layed down they told me they would be taking some more pics and monitor my breathing first.  A little while after that they had me sit up and that was it!  I had to ask if they radiated me yet and they said yup!  They didn't tell me before they did it, which was a good thing becuase I kept waiting for that and knew once they told me, my heart would start to race and my breathing would get faster.  I ended up getting 3 more tats today, and one of them is on my neck, same place in the front/side of your neck where you take your pulse, except on the left side.  She tried to make it as small as possible, but still...always the reminder I guess.  I came home and applied my 100% aloe followed by some aquaphor.  All in all, radiation was a breeze...we will just have to wait and see how it affects me in a week or two!
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: May 17, 2011 04:59AM thegood5 wrote: ReadingMama~ the same thing keeps happening to me with the marker right in my clevage...they marked me on Friday but my boosts don't start until next Wed.  They told me to try to keep the sticker over the marker...it came off as I was changing in the dressing room!  My husband had to keep taking the green sharpie to me all weekend.  When I went in today, I asked for a different sticker they had used before that really sticks, and the newer tech slapped it on and had my skin all pinched under it.  By this afternoon I couldn't take the pain of that anymore and took it off, along with a little bit of skin...ouch!  I could hardly stand it when my hubby sharpied me again, and he looked like he was going to cry while doing it!  Can't wait to go back again tomorrow for another sticker...not!  I'm wondering if the square attatchment they put on for you for your boosts is the same thing they put on for me for my one zap they give right on my sternum to get a node there.  I am all red and blistery because they zoom in just a few inches from my skin.  Every place else, under my arm and back are feeling fine, just a little red.  Hope you are feeling better!

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2011 02:57PM thegood5 wrote: The dreaded day arrived today...known for months that I would be having a PET scan after rads were done.  Been on edge all day...just called my Nurse Navigator and got the AWESOME news.....no cancer to be found!!!  I am so thrilled!  For those of you who don't know my history, I had a tumor on my liver from the beginning of my BC dx, and after my chemo treatments it really had shrunk.  Depending on what this PET showed, I would possibly have a liver resection to have to tumor removed, or there was a chance it would spread and then I would just be on chemo to hopefully control it.  Well, there is no evidence of anything on my liver anymore!!  I meet with my onc on Fri and will discuss whether or not I should still look into a resection.  Right now I'm on cloud 9!  1 celebratory pina colada down, many more to go!

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2011 04:22AM thegood5 wrote: MaggieMc2, welcome!  My onc told me 4 wks after, but I had a lumpectomy and you may need to wait a little longer with a bigger surgery.  Basically it is to let the scar heal completly. Got the simulation done today.  Gotta say, it was a piece of cake.  there was a woman at my church who came up to me one day (only met her once before) and just started telling me her horror story about her simulation and how I should take a nerve pill before I go and get ready for uncomfortable positions and markers and yada yada yada...glad I didn't take it to heart, because everything went so smoothly today and thanks to all of the ladies from the March rads thread, I felt like I knew exactly what was coming.  I guess everyone is different, but compared to everything else, this was a breeze.  Got my 4 tats and was told I will probably have to get more. They need to zap me under my arm, my left breast and a node that is right in front of my sternum.  I'm going to feel like a fried chicken after all that!

Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 01:51PM thegood5 wrote: I also went crazy when I found out I would be losing my hair.  I actually went to Target and picked a bunch of cute baseball style hats, but they were a cable knit, like a sweater.  I chose some that went down a little further in the back.  I also went and bought a bandana in every color and often do the pirate look.  I ordered 2 little caps from Headcovers.com that you wear underneath your hat to keep it from sliding.  I cut my hair short right before chemo started and then started wearing hats and bandana's around the house and to the store just to get used to the look.  I always said this was God's joke...I hate wearing hats!  But after a week, they were my security and even though I'm a month out from chemo and have hair getting close to an inch long, I still hate when my hubby takes my hat off to rub my head...love the rubbing part, hate the way I look.  I never wore a wig...put one on and looked like Dora the Explorer..it just puffed up and looked weird.  I know some people love to wear wigs tho, it's just a matter of finding the right one for you.  Throw on a great pair of earrings and maybe that will help you feel better about the hat thing....I went "big earring shopping" also and feel good when I can jazz up my look!  Good luck and I hope all goes well with your treatments!
Posts.Title: When to buy head gear DivineMrsM lago

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2011 05:34AM - edited Jun 21, 2011 05:34AM by thegood5 RockyM~i know exactly what you mean....I will be feeling so normal and then I look in the mirror or get a glimpse of my shadow (lost hair during chemo) and it's like "DAMN!  that's right....I have cancer".  Sorry to hear you had a rough moment during your MRI.  It's amazing how our minds wander, isn't it?  It's like we plan out this whole story in our head of how it might be and it brings us to tears, making it feel like that's how it really is...I often visualize my husband and kids around my house after I'm gone.  Not a thought I want to have but sometimes I'm thinking it without realizing it.  I had to laugh at you buying a webkinz...we have about 50 of them ( I have 3 daughters) and they have some pretty fancy houses online!  Hope your daughter has fun with it!  Take care!
Posts.Title: It's All So Surreal Rockym calamtykel

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2011 02:44PM thegood5 wrote: I just had a lumpectomy last week and 4 nodes removed...same story as yours, nodes were neg, but margins were'nt clear.  Going back for 2nd round possibly next Fri. if surgeon can fit me n between vacations!  Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: How many others had to have more surgery? BioAdoptMom3 cantgarden

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 09:29PM thegood5 wrote: After reading the Twilight book, I always said to my husband that Edward could swoop down and bite me anytime....When I had my port put in, he told me that now Edward could just pop a straw in my port and I could be his juice box!  My cousin even made me a shirt that is pink and says in fancy letters "Edwards Juice Box" with a glittery arrow pointing to my port....I Love it!  And when I wear it out and people look at me strange, I love to tell them the story!
Posts.Title: chemo & my boyfreind annette40 littletower

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2011 07:14AM thegood5 wrote: cantgarden~  I just had a 2nd done, same as you, neg margins but just needed to be sure.  I'm glad I did it so I won't have to worry in the future with "what if's".  Turns out they wouldn't have even needed to do it, but better safe than sorry!  You wouldn't have even known they went in there again from the looks of the scar, just a tiny bit of bruising around it, nothing like the bruising the first time.  It was a little more sore this time around, but nothing unbearable.  Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: How many others had to have more surgery? BioAdoptMom3 cantgarden

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2011 10:07PM thegood5 wrote: Dragonfly1, please tell me you printed that one out to take and show that insensitive #&*@$!   Love it! marjie, couldn't agree more....appreciated that people were trying to be nice, but knowing the whole time that they were probably thinking "blech!".....on my chemo days my husband would just look at me and pout or give me a "oh Honey", which I appreciated even more that he didn't sugar coat it and tell me I looked good.  There were times when I looked like absolute crap, a lovely shade of chemo-green, and someone would say I looked so good.  If I would roll my eyes or something and they would ask why, I would say "oh come on, what else are you going to say?  You aren't going to tell me I look like hell".  I guess those were my "leave me alone" kind of days....but it really helps me to realize the things I now say to other people.

Posts.Content: May 16, 2011 03:33PM thegood5 wrote: yes, that's our "wine wall"....yes, I drink, curse me , that's "probably why I got cancer"..lol!  Thanks for the compliments, I think my girls are cuties!   When I was at rads today, a woman probably in her 30's came out and I had never seen her there before.  She was beautiful, and her hair was shorter than mine, kind of the fresh buzzed look.  Her hair was dark and she had a tan and makeup on and she just looked so pretty and confident...wishing I could feel that comfortable going out without a hat.  I think the same thing you do when I see someone out and about and their hair is really short...just a short cut and don't think anything about it, but for some reason when I look in the mirror, all I can see is someone with cancer.  Blah.  Just ready for some bangs and then I think I will feel better about it.

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2011 04:39PM thegood5 wrote: DoubleWhammy~the thing is, if I saw you out in public, I wouldn't think a thing of it.  That has been a big change for me since my dx...I don't judge anyone I see..you don't know what their life story is.  If I see someone that looks like they may be going thru some kind of treatment or something, I don't feel pity for them, I feel proud for them.  It's damn hard to go out looking different than before, but you should be proud for all you have conquered and try not to let it get to you that people may look at you, you are a fighter!  I think you are beautiful, and as I've gotten to know many amazing women on here, we are all in this together, and there are A LOT of us.  As my sister tells me, I may not have much hair, but at least I "have" hair...thankful for every day that I'm here!  xo

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2011 08:48AM thegood5 wrote: slcst12~I feel your stress!  My husband and I went to a dinner in DC with a group of friends and I was so tired of wearing scarves (never wore a wig).  I decided to make it my "coming out" moment.  I figured that no one in DC knows me, so why not?  I was so self conscious all night...felt like everyone was looking at me, but then had to stop and think that I was looking around at people too and it didn't mean they were staring at just me.  I worried about it all night, and look back now and realize I made a bigger deal out of it than I needed to.  No matter when  you decide to go topless, you will be second guessing if that was the right time or not.  If you decide to go topless to your dinner, put on a pretty pair of earring's, a pretty smile, and embrace the fact that you are a strong woman...that is very empowering.  Good luck with whatever you decide and have fun!  (when I see women when I'm out and about who have really short hair, I see  strength!)

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 10:36AM thegood5 wrote: i had the worst experience in that class.  the girl was about 25 and brought along her bratty 5 yr. old son.  We started a half hour late because she was late, had a lot of the wrong kits and didn't have wigs or scarves along.  She paid more attention to her son than us.  No one got anything out of it.  We also were done a half hour early.  We knew how it was supposed to be done because we watched the video in the beginning, and on a scale of 1-10, she gets a 0!  They had enought complaints about her that the ACS called us all for our opinion and offered us another class.  The free makeup was great, but I was there more for the experience and getting to know others.  She didn't even have us go around and introduce ourselves and we didn't find out her name until the end.  One woman even got up and left because it was so bad.  But I have heard how great those classes are, we just happened to get a dud.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2011 08:51AM thegood5 wrote: my hair started to fall out on the 15 th day, buzzed it that night.  Started using a lint roller to grab the little pieces for about a week after that and then had my hubby shave my head with my razor because my head was sore...I think from the little tiny stubble that  you could barely see.  He did this 2 x's and then it wasn't sore any more after that.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2011 01:36PM thegood5 wrote: EshLou, this whole thing just sucks, doesn't it?  So sorry to hear you had such an inconsiderate onc...but really glad you got a second opinion!  And congrats on how far you have come!!  I have days like that too, where the fear just eats away at me, and rather than dwell on it, I try to find the positive, which can be really hard!  I was dx in Sept. and am HER2+, so I was told that Herceptin would work wonderfully for me and they thought that my survival rate was 90%+.  Then I had a PET scan and they found a spot on my liver.  I, like you, was told this is extremely rare...ususally people are either covered on their liver, or have no spots at all.  I was a bit of a medical mystery also.  I went to see a top onc at the University of Pa and he agreed totally with my onc here at home that this was rare and in his 20+ years, he only knew of 8 people who went thru this.    After recieving my first tx of chemo, all tumors had either shrunk or melted away totally.  They were a bit confused about the met on my liver, because at one point it looked solid with liquid in the center, which made them think that it possibly was a cyst instead.  But the fact that it was shrinking made them think it was cancer.  They also found some other tiny spots but said that is not surprising, most everyone has cyst-like spots on their liver.  So now that I finished radiation yesterday (yea!)  I will be having a PET scan next week followed by a liver MRI.  If no other spots have shown up, I will be having a liver resection in a month or so.  I saw the top liver surgeon at U of PA and although we want answers and someone to tell us all will be fine, even she couldn't do that for me about the surgery.  She said that it would be a difficult surgery, but well worth it if no other spots have come about.  Some people's cases can be kind of cut and dry, and other's, like ours, are extremely confusing to not only us, but the dr's too.  I was told back in Feb. that they found a spot on my sternum that was hidden by a positive node that I already knew would be getting rads.  One Dr. was saying he is almost positive that it was a met, and another saying he doubted it.  It was the only spot that the chemo didn't shrink.  I had a sternal bone biop done to see, since I would need it radiated if it was a met, and it came back negative.  They said that we will never really know if it had been cancer at one time or not.  Could just be a discoloration on my bone.  So...long story short...sometimes even the Dr's don't know and yes, we need to be our own advocates during this crazy time.  Hang in there and trust your gut.  Wish I could give you a hug to help calm your worries.
Posts.Title: Plse help am I stage 4? EshLou thegood5

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2011 07:20AM thegood5 wrote: wow, I am so glad to happen upon this thread!  I too have just one liver met, and have been talking to a liver surgeon about a resection.  She wants to wait 3 months since I just finished chemo, herceptin reduced the size of the met.  She wants to make sure no other mets form in the next 3 months, that way they wouldn't have to put me thru the surgery for no good reason.  They consider my case extremely rare, and until now, I have yet to find anyone else going thru the same thing I am.

Posts.Title: Stage IV with Liver mets (HER2+, ER+/PR +). Journey so far Fatima gonegirl

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 09:20AM thegood5 wrote: windy2011:  unfortunately, welcome to the site.  Our stories sound very similar...I posted a few above you the other day.  I recently found out that a possible met was found on my sternum hiding behind a cancerous node that we already knew about.  I am going to have a scan done after my lumpectomy next week to see if it is benign...fingers crossed.  If it is a met, I will have it radiated along with the node, but it is risky and will include a portion of my heart.  When I meet with a Dr., they just tell me that there is no right answer right now for what my treatments may be, including a possible liver resection as long as there are not any other mets that form in the next 3 months.  I am her2nu+, so I was on herceptin (they did my chemo first) and it melted away all tumors except for the liver, which has gone down considerably and the bone one which hasn't changed at all, therefore making us hope it is benign.  Good luck to you with everything and keep in touch!
Posts.Title: Stage IV with Liver mets (HER2+, ER+/PR +). Journey so far Fatima gonegirl

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2011 11:15AM thegood5 wrote: I too have a liver met, just one.  I met with a liver surgeon last week about a resection.  Having a lumpectomy next week, and then radiation.  Waiting 3 months and then having a scan to see if the tumor is still responding to the herceptin.  just finished 6 tx of carbo, taxoterrible and herceptin.  the herceptin has reduced my liver tumor considerably and melted away my breast one and lymph node.  Will be on herceptin forever.
Posts.Title: Stage IV with Liver mets (HER2+, ER+/PR +). Journey so far Fatima gonegirl
